On Nov 29, 2006, at 3:21 PM, spdomin wrote:

> Greetings,
>
> I have the f=
ollowing set of requests to make to the Cantera project.
>
> 1.  Please do =
not force the platform to use "g++ -MM" to generate  
> makefile dependenci=
es.  That can be the default, but allow it to be  
> specified through the =
CXX_DEPENDS (or some other) environment  
> variable.
Sure, that's easy.


=
> 2.  Really allow Cantera not to be built with f2c even on a Linux  
> pla=
tform.  We have a set of odd platforms that say they are Linux  
> but are =
really cross compilers.  Cantera always builds f2c if the  
> uname is Linu=
x.
OK, also easy to fix.
>
> 3. We have built Cantera on about 10 different=
 platforms (flavors  
> of linux, sun, ibm, AMD with pgi, etc.). We note a =
number of  
> warnings related to statements not being able to be reached, =
 
> annoying =93used but not declared=94 warnings and some more troubling  =

> warnings that indicate that virtual methods are attempted to be  
> hidd=
en, or more clearly, overloaded. In general, one may not  
> overload a vir=
tual method. Usually when one finds oneself trying to  
> overload a virtua=
l method, there is room for design improvement. I  
> am still learning the=
 code design, so I am not yet in a position to  
> provide a solution.
If I=
 understand your point (I may not), you are saying that a virtual  
method =
declared in a base class should not also be defined there -  
only in subcl=
asses, so that the subclass implementation does not  
"hide" the base class=
 implementation. Is that right?

I prefer to define all virtual methods in =
the base class with some  
default behavior - usually throwing an exception=
 or printing an error  
message if called.  This allows subclasses to reimp=
lement only those  
methods that are relevant for them.    For example, a t=
ransport  
manager class for a solid should not need to define the "viscosi=
ty()"  
method, even though a virtual method is provided in the base class =
 
for use by transport managers for which viscosity is a relevant  
transpo=
rt property.  What we do is define method "viscosity()" in the  
base class=
 to throw an exception if it is called. In this way,  
subclasses for which=
 viscosity is meaningful and which reimplement  
the viscosity() method wor=
k fine, but if a user tries to invoke the  
viscosity method on an inapprop=
riate subclass, an exception results.   
We also overload virtual functions=
 defined in base classes to provide  
optional initializations that some su=
bclasses may require; in such  
cases, the base class method is typically d=
efined to do nothing.

It turns out to be very convenient to put methods in=
 the base classes  
that only some subclasses need, "viscosity" being only =
one example.  
While it would be possible to design a C++ class hierarchy f=
or which  
this is not required, it makes it much simpler to write the Pyth=
on  
and MATLAB interface code if the C++ class structure is kept  
relativ=
ely simple, at least for classes that are meant to be exposed  
in Python a=
nd MATLAB.   The basic structure in Cantera is one base  
class for major c=
lass "families" (Thermo, Kinetics, and Transport),  
and a single level of =
subclasses within each family.  Keeping to this  
simple structure involves=
 some compromises that might not be done if  
one were only interested in C=
++ code, but it greatly simplifies the  
Python/MATLAB interfacing, because=
 all subclasses within a family can  
be accessed with base class pointers.=


Anyway, this is a long answer to your question, and I may not have  
comp=
letely understood what you are saying.  Let me know if I have  
misundersto=
od.
>

> We have the above two items resolved in our local version of  
> C=
antera 1.7.0 and will begin to resolve some of the warnings noted  
> in (3=
). What is the procedure of pushing back these changes to the  
> Cantera r=
epository? We would like to become part of the Cantera  
> community and co=
ntribute to the improvement of this tool.
>
That's easy: become a developer=
.   All you need to do is register at  
SourceForge if you haven't yet, and=
 then send me  
(dgoodwin@...) your SourceForge member name.  We ca=
n discuss  
this further off-line.

Thanks for your interest!


> Regards,
=
>
> Stefan
>
>
> On 11/18/06 12:33 PM, "Steven C. DeCaluwe" <decal_12@yahoo=
.com> wrote:
>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> Dr. Goodwin,
>>
>> Thank you for the advice. =
 Upgrading to 2006b resolved the issue  
>> completely.
>>
>> Just as a tip=
 to anyone else, 1.7 seems to take exception to  
>> Python being stored in=
side the 'Program Files' folder (or anything  
>> with a space in the name,=
 I assume).  I don't believe this was an  
>> issue in previous releases, b=
ut if you're having trouble importing  
>> phases this may be at the heart =
of it.
>>
>> Thanks again,
>> Steven
>>
>> ----- Original Message ----
>> F=
rom: David Goodwin <dgoodwin@...>
>> To: cantera@yahoogroups.com
>>=
 Sent: Thursday, November 16, 2006 9:56:42 AM
>> Subject: Re: [cantera] Can=
tera 1.7.0 for Windows--Installation issues
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> The MATLAB toolb=
ox in the MSI installer was created using MATLAB  
>> 2006b.  So maybe it i=
s a difference between 2006a and 2006b. At  
>> some point recently, the MA=
TLAB people changed the file extension  
>> for MEX files on Windows from "=
dll" to "mexw32". Cantera  
>> implements this change, but maybe your older=
 MATLAB is still  
>> expecting an extension of "dll".  I would suggest tha=
t you either  
>> upgrade your MATLAB version, or compile Cantera from sour=
ce code,  
>> which will probably work with older versions, and edit the  
=
>> SetupCantera project to install ctmethods.dll, instead of  
>> ctmethods=
.mexw32 (if that is the problem).
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> On Nov 16, 2006, at 5:56 A=
M, Steven C. DeCaluwe wrote:
>>
>>>
>>> Hello Everybody,
>>>
>>> After comp=
leting the following steps:
>>> -running the msi installer for windows (Win=
dows XP, Matlab2006a)
>>> -installing Python 2.5
>>> -installing the relate=
d numarray
>>> -running Cantera-1.7. 0.win32-py2. 5.exe, and
>>> -changing =
the environment 'Path' variable to find Python 2.5,  
>>> rather than 2.4
>=
>>
>>> I get the following error when I try to make Cantera objects in  
>>=
> Matlab from any cti file (I've tried using the 'air' function, as  
>>> w=
ell as 'importPhase'
>>>
>>> ------------ --------- --------- --------- ---=
------ ---------  
>>> --------- --------- --------- --------- --------- --=
-------  
>>> --------- --------- --------- ----
>>> ??? Invalid MEX-file '=
C:\Program Files\Cantera\ MATLAB\toolbox\  
>>> cantera\ctmethod s.mexw32' =
: The specified procedure could not be  
>>> found.
>>>
>>> .
>>> Error in =
=3D=3D> XML_Node.XML_ Node at 11
>>>    x.id =3D ctmethods(10, 15,0,src) ; =
% newxml(name)
>>>
>>> Error in =3D=3D> Solution.Solution at 30
>>> doc =3D=
 XML_Node('doc' ,src);
>>>
>>> Error in =3D=3D> importPhase at 7
>>>   s =
=3D Solution(file, name);
>>> ------------ --------- --------- --------- --=
------- ---------  
>>> --------- --------- --------- --------- --------- -=
--------  
>>> --------- --------- --------- -----
>>>
>>> Any idea what th=
is could be?  Has anyone else experienced this  
>>> problem?  Several of u=
s at the University of Maryland have run  
>>> into it w/ the 1.7 release. =
 Could it be an error with my 'mex - 
>>> setup'?
>>>
>>> Thanks,
>>> Steve=
n DeCaluwe
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> Check out the all-new Yahoo! Mail beta <http://u=
s.rd.yahoo.com/ 
>>> evt=3D43257/*http://advision.webevents.yahoo.com/mailb=
eta>  - Fire  
>>> up a more powerful email and get things done faster.
>>
